text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with patatas bravas that's right a
lot of people think that means brave
potatoes it doesn't it means fierce
potatoes and if there's one thing I've
learned hanging out with supermodels all
these years is that fierce is good and
speaking of good pretty much any recipe
from Spain is going to be awesome and
this is one of the best of all time so
check it out all right step one we're
going to get some water ready to boil
our potatoes most people do this in just
plain salted water but we're not most
people so we're going to flavor the
water up I'm going to add some salt some
smoked paprika a little bit of cumin and
two bay leaves alright we're going to
bring that up to a simmer and we're
going to simmer that for ten minutes to
extract some of those flavors and while
that's simmering for 10 minutes we will
prep our potatoes and I'm using just
good old-fashioned Idaho russet potatoes
you're going to want to stay away from
those red potatoes those are a little
too waxy for this you want something
nice and starchy so I'm going to cut
those in half like that and then each
half I'm going to cut lengthwise twice
into three pieces and then those pieces
I'll cut across to make like 1-inch
cubes
alright you know the drill pick a shape
pick a size and stick with it and you
can just hold those in cold water until
you're ready alright by this time our
seasoned liquid has simmered for ten
minutes I'm of course going to drain the
water from the potatoes and dump those
into this mixture all right that's going
to take probably three four or five
minutes to come back to a simmer you can
just leave it on high heat and once
those start boiling again you're going
to cook it for about I don't know four
or five minutes approximately we want
them almost tender alright they
shouldn't be too firm but yet they
shouldn't be falling apart tender like
you're going to make mashed potatoes you
want to pull them out just before
they're all the way done
and the easiest way to check is just
with a tip of a paring knife right here
I can feel mine we're a little too firm
so I'll let them boil for another minute
so just to give it a percentage let's
say like 90 percent cooked at that point
you're going to take your strainer and
pull those out of that liquid and you
want to transfer those onto a wire rack
to cool now this is very critical
you want them to air dry and cool down
completely before you fry them this is
what gives them that crusty crunchy
texture okay so I don't care how hungry
you are let these dry and cool down
completely alright while we're waiting
we can go ahead and make our spicy aioli
top these with in a mortar I have some
sliced garlic with a pinch of salt I'm
also going to add some smoked paprika
and a little Chipotle and I'm going to
crush that into a paste and when that
happens I'm going to add some mayonnaise
should you make it homemade yes did I
know so we're going to dump in some
mayonnaise and a nice big splash of
sherry vinegar you're definitely going
to need some acidity here
some people like lemon juice I like the
sherry vinegar much better but up to you
so I'm going to stir that in and then
I'm going to give it a little shot of
tomato paste in the middle of summer
when there's lots of fresh tomatoes
around I'll do a version of this that
has diced fresh tomatoes in it but here
just a little pace for color and acidity
then you're going to taste and adjust
and at this point I was like you know
what I need a little more vinegar and a
little bit of cayenne so stir that up
and refrigerate until needed of course
that can be done ahead of time and
please feel free to make extra that is
good on literally everything alright so
that's done and then last but not least
I'm going to do a little bit of a
seasoning salt to put on the potatoes
after they're fried and that's going to
be fine salt freshly ground black pepper
smoked paprika some more Chipotle which
is going to give it some nice heat if
you want extra heat add some cayenne but
don't forget the aioli is also spicy and
then I'm going to give that a mix with
my freakishly small Estonian wooden
spice ladle alright so give it a stir
and that's done and we're ready to fry
so I'm going to use a cast-iron skillet
on high heat with about an inch and a
half of vegetable oil in it I don't use
a thermometer I just throw a potato in
and when it starts bubbling viciously I
know the oils hot all right so that's my
little tester potato I ate that one and
by the way it looks like the pan is
rusty it's not that's just the remnants
from some earlier frying so I am
recycling this oil it was still very
clean and once the oil is hot we're
going to put in our now dried and cooled
potatoes and they're going to fry up
awesomely alright as far as time I don't
know five six minutes maybe how do you
know they're going to be golden brown
and extremely crunchy and this is what
they should sound like
oh yeah and when you're ready to serve
throw them in a bowl give them a toss
with that seasoning salt throw them out
of plates and then you eat him with a
toothpick which makes it even more fun
by the way listen to this that was not
edited to make it sound more delicious
than it really was was incredible but
wait there's more don't forget to top it
with your spicy aioli maybe some fresh
parsley stick in some toothpicks and
that is done patatas bravas this is one
of the world's great potato dishes of
all time crispy crunchy spicy just
what's the word I'm looking for
fierce that's it and not just regular
fierce we're talking borderline Sasha
Fierce they're that good so I really
hope you give these a try head over to
